Category.Name: Wordplay / Puns
Category.Description: Jokes that rely on clever or humorous use of words, especially by exploiting multiple meanings or similar sounds.
Category.Example: I'm reading a book about anti-gravity. It's impossible to put down.
Why did the bicycle fall over? Because it was two tired!

Category.Name: Malapropisms
Category.Description: Jokes that derive humor from the incorrect use of a word in place of one with a similar sound, often with nonsensical or amusing results.
Category.Example: He had to use a fire distinguisher.
My sister has extra-century perception.

Category.Name: Non-sequiturs
Category.Description: Jokes where the punchline is a statement that is absurdly unrelated to the setup.
Category.Example: What's the difference between a duck? One of its legs is both the same.
I asked the librarian if they had books about paranoia. She whispered, 'They're right behind you!'

Category.Name: Irony / Sarcasm
Category.Description: Jokes that use language that normally signifies the opposite, typically for humorous or emphatic effect. Sarcasm is a sharp, bitter, or cutting expression or remark; a bitter gibe or taunt, often conveyed through irony.
Category.Example: A traffic cop got his license suspended for unpaid parking tickets.
Oh, a surprise party for me? I had absolutely no idea, despite finding the decorations and overhearing all the planning.

Category.Name: Absurdity / Surrealism
Category.Description: Jokes that feature illogical, bizarre, or dreamlike scenarios and imagery for comedic effect.
Category.Example: A man walks into a bar with a slab of asphalt under his arm. He says: 'A beer please, and one for the road.'
My dog is a great dancer. His favorite move is the 'roof'.

Category.Name: Double Entendres
Category.Description: Jokes that are phrased to be understood in two ways, one of which is often risqué or suggestive.
Category.Example: Marriage is a fine institution, but I'm not ready for an institution.

A linguistics professor was lecturing his class. "In English," he said, "a double negative forms a positive. However, in some languages, such as Russian, a double negative remains a negative. But there isn't a single language, not one, in which a double positive can express a negative." A voice from the back of the room piped up, "Yeah, right."

Category.Name: Misdirection
Category.Description: Jokes that lead the listener to expect a certain outcome or meaning, then deliver a surprising and different one.
Category.Example: I used to play piano by ear, but now I use my hands.
I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She seemed surprised.

Category.Name: Self-referential / Meta-humor
Category.Description: Jokes that refer to the joke itself, the act of telling a joke, or the conventions of humor.
Category.Example: This is a joke. It has a setup and a punchline.
Why did the comedian get booed off stage? His jokes weren't self-aware enough.

Category.Name: Animals
Category.Description: Jokes where animals are the main characters or subject, often behaving in human-like ways or in funny situations.
Category.Example: What do you call a fish with no eyes? Fsh!
Why don't skeletons fight each other? They don't have the guts.

Category.Name: Politics
Category.Description: Jokes that satirize or comment on political figures, systems, or events.
Category.Example: Why don't politicians go to the beach? Because they have trouble telling the truth from the lying.
A politician is one who shakes your hand before elections and your confidence after.

Category.Name: Religion
Category.Description: Jokes that involve religious figures, beliefs, practices, or institutions, often by highlighting human interpretations or paradoxes.
Category.Example: An atheist, a vegan, and a CrossFit enthusiast walk into a bar. I only know because they told everyone within two minutes.
Moses had the first tablet that could connect to the cloud.

Category.Name: Sex / Adult
Category.Description: Jokes that deal with sexual themes, innuendo, or adult situations, often relying on suggestion or explicit content for humor. (Note: Examples will be kept mild).
Category.Example: Why is it so hard for a pirate to learn the alphabet? Because they can spend years at C!
What did the O say to the Q? You've got a cute little tail there!

Category.Name: Workplace
Category.Description: Jokes centered around office life, colleagues, bosses, and common work situations.
Category.Example: My boss told me to have a good day. So I went home.
I'm not saying I hate my job, but if it were on fire and I had a glass of water, I'd drink it.

Category.Name: Relationships / Marriage
Category.Description: Jokes about the dynamics of romantic relationships, dating, marriage, and family life.
Category.Example: My wife and I were happy for twenty years. Then we met.
I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She looked surprised.

Category.Name: Children / Parenting
Category.Description: Jokes about the challenges, joys, and humorous aspects of raising children and being a parent.
Category.Example: Why did the kids give their dad a blanket for his birthday? They heard he was cool.
Parenting is mostly just informing kids how many more minutes they have of something.

Category.Name: School / Exams / Students
Category.Description: Jokes related to education, teachers, students, homework, exams, and school life.
Category.Example: Why was the math book sad? Because it had too many problems.

Teacher: "Kids, what does the chicken give you?" Student: "Meat!" Teacher: "Very good! Now what does the pig give you?" Student: "Bacon!" Teacher: "Great! And what does the fat cow give you?" Student: "Homework!"

Category.Name: Ethnicity / Nationality / Stereotypes
Category.Description: Jokes that play on perceived cultural traits or stereotypes associated with specific ethnic groups or nationalities. (Note: Examples will aim for lightheartedness and avoid offensiveness).
Category.Example: An Englishman, an Irishman, and a Scotsman are in a pub. The barman says, "Is this some kind of joke?"
Why do French people eat snails? They don't like fast food.

Category.Name: Technology / IT / Programming
Category.Description: Jokes about computers, software, the internet, programming, and the quirks of technology.
Category.Example: There are 10 types of people in the world: those who understand binary, and those who don't.
Why did the programmer quit his job? Because he didn't get arrays.

Category.Name: Science / Math / Academia
Category.Description: Jokes that involve scientific principles, mathematical concepts, or the academic world.
Category.Example: Why can you never trust atoms? They make up everything!

A biologist, a chemist, and a statistician are out hunting. The biologist shoots at a deer and misses 5ft to the left. The chemist takes a shot and misses 5ft to the right. The statistician yells, "We got him!"

Category.Name: Dark / Morbid humor
Category.Description: Jokes that find humor in serious, grim, or taboo subjects like death, misfortune, or disaster.
Category.Example: "I have a vest that's bulletproof, fireproof, stabproof, and waterproof. It's also extremely uncomfortable." "What's it made of?" "Irony."
My grandfather has the heart of a lion and a lifetime ban from the zoo.

Category.Name: Pop Culture / Celebrity
Category.Description: Jokes that reference movies, TV shows, music, celebrities, or other aspects of popular culture.
Category.Example: Why was Star Wars Episode IV, V, and VI made before I, II, and III? Because in charge of sequence, Yoda was.
What's the difference between a well-dressed man on a unicycle and a poorly-dressed man on a bicycle? Attire.

Category.Name: Historical / Intellectual humor
Category.Description: Jokes that require some knowledge of history, literature, philosophy, or other intellectual subjects to be understood.
Category.Example: René Descartes walks into a bar. The bartender asks, "Would you like a drink?" Descartes replies, "I think not," and promptly disappears.
What's brown and sticky? A stick.

Category.Name: One-liners
Category.Description: Jokes that are delivered in a single, concise sentence or phrase.
Category.Example: I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She seemed surprised.
I'm on a whiskey diet. I've lost three days already.

Category.Name: Knock-knock jokes
Category.Description: A structured call-and-response joke format starting with 'Knock, knock.' 'Who's there?'.
Category.Example: Knock, knock. Who's there? Lettuce. Lettuce who? Lettuce in, it's cold out here!
Knock, knock. Who's there? Cows go. Cows go who? No, cows go moo!

Category.Name: Riddles
Category.Description: Jokes phrased as a question or statement with a double or veiled meaning, put forth as a puzzle to be solved.
Category.Example: What has an eye, but cannot see? A needle.
What is full of holes but still holds water? A sponge.

Category.Name: Light bulb jokes
Category.Description: A formulaic joke asking how many people of a certain group are needed to change a light bulb, with the punchline playing on stereotypes of that group.
Category.Example: How many programmers does it take to change a light bulb? None, that's a hardware problem.
How many surrealists does it take to change a light bulb? A fish.

Category.Name: Yo mama jokes
Category.Description: A type of insult humor where the 'yo mama' (your mother) is the target of a hyperbolic and often absurd put-down.
Category.Example: Yo mama's so fat, when she wears a yellow raincoat, people yell "Taxi!"
Yo mama's so old, her birth certificate says 'Expired'.

Category.Name: Anti-jokes
Category.Description: Jokes where the listener is set up to expect a traditional punchline, but instead receives a mundane, logical, or unfunny statement.
Category.Example: Why did the chicken cross the road? To get to the other side.
What's red and bad for your teeth? A brick.

Category.Name: Shaggy dog stories
Category.Description: A long-winded, rambling joke with an anticlimactic or nonsensical punchline; the humor comes from the lengthy buildup to nothing.
Category.Example: A man spent years training his dog to talk. Finally, after much effort, the dog looks up and says, "You know, for a long time I've been meaning to ask you... why do you keep hitting me with that newspaper?" The humor is in the expectation vs. the mundane reveal after a long implied setup.
A man walks into a bar and orders a drink. The bartender serves him. The man enjoys his drink. (This is a very short shaggy dog story, the point is the lack of a punchline where one is expected).

Category.Name: Deadpan delivery
Category.Description: A style of comedic delivery where jokes are told in a deliberately serious, expressionless, or unemotional manner. The humor often arises from the contrast between the absurd content and the serious delivery. (Note: The examples are the jokes themselves, the deadpan aspect is in how they'd be told).
Category.Example: I'm not a vegetarian because I love animals. I'm a vegetarian because I hate plants.
My therapist told me the way to achieve true inner peace is to finish what I start. So far I've finished two bags of MnMs and a chocolate cake. I feel better already.

Category.Name: Satirical
Category.Description: Jokes that use humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices, particularly in the context of contemporary politics and other topical issues.
Category.Example: The government is a bit like a baby. An alimentary canal with a big appetite at one end and no sense of responsibility at the other.
In order to make a small fortune in the stock market, you should start with a large fortune.

Category.Name: Parody / Spoof
Category.Description: Jokes that imitate the style of a particular writer, artist, or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
Category.Example: "To be or not to be, that is the question... whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles, and by opposing end them... or just order a pizza?"
If Dr. Seuss wrote horror: "I do not like them, Sam-I-Am, these things that go bump in the night, I am."

Category.Name: Slapstick / Physical comedy
Category.Description: Humor based on clumsy actions and humorously embarrassing events, often involving exaggerated physical violence or accidents. (Note: XML examples describe scenarios).
Category.Example: A man slips on a banana peel and lands in a wedding cake. (Visual description)
Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field! (Can be seen as physical if imagining the scarecrow).

Category.Name: Insults / Roasts
Category.Description: Jokes intended to mock or disparage a person or thing, often in a witty or humorous way.
Category.Example: You're not the dumbest person in the world, but you'd better hope they don't die.
Is your family tree a cactus? Because everyone on it is a prick.

Category.Name: Wholesome / Clean humor
Category.Description: Jokes that are free from offensive, risqué, or controversial content, suitable for all audiences.
Category.Example: Why don't scientists trust atoms? Because they make up everything!
What do you call a bear with no teeth? A gummy bear!

Category.Name: Dark / Gallows humor
Category.Description: Humor that treats serious, frightening, or taboo subjects like death, disease, or warfare with bitter amusement. (Similar to Morbid Humor but can be more about coping with dire situations).
Category.Example: "Well, apart from that, Mrs. Lincoln, how was the play?"
I have a stepladder. My real ladder left when I was a kid.

Category.Name: Dad jokes
Category.Description: Typically short, pun-based, or corny jokes told by fathers, often eliciting groans rather than laughter.
Category.Example: What do you call a fish with no eyes? Fsh!
I'm afraid for the calendar. Its days are numbered.

Category.Name: Blonde jokes
Category.Description: Jokes that play on the stereotype of blonde women being unintelligent. (Note: These can be controversial; examples will be mild and focus on naivety).
Category.Example: A blonde walks into a library and asks, "Can I have a burger and fries?" The librarian says, "Ma'am, this is a library." The blonde whispers, "Oh, sorry. (in a low voice) Can I have a burger and fries?"
Why did the blonde stare at the orange juice container? Because it said "concentrate."

Category.Name: Programmer / Nerd jokes
Category.Description: Jokes that rely on knowledge of computer science, mathematics, science fiction, or other 'nerdy' topics.
Category.Example: Why do programmers prefer dark mode? Because light attracts bugs.
There are 10 types of people: those who understand binary and those who don't, and those who didn't expect this joke to be in base 3.

Category.Name: Ethnic / National jokes
Category.Description: Jokes that target specific ethnic or national groups, often based on stereotypes. (Reiteration of earlier category, focusing on 'target').
Category.Example: An Englishman, an Irishman, and a Scotsman walk out of a pub. This is not the setup for a joke; they just had a nice evening.
Why did the American bring a ladder to the bar? He heard the drinks were on the house.

Category.Name: Lawyer / Doctor / Engineer jokes
Category.Description: Jokes that play on stereotypes or common perceptions of professions like lawyers, doctors, or engineers.
Category.Example: Why did the lawyer bring a ladder to court? To reach a higher settlement.

A doctor, a lawyer, and an engineer were discussing whose profession was oldest. The doctor said, "Well, Eve was made from Adam's rib, and that was a surgical procedure." The engineer said, "But before that, order was created from chaos, and that was an engineering feat." The lawyer smiled and said, "And who do you think created the chaos?"

Category.Name: Gender-based humor
Category.Description: Jokes that derive humor from stereotypes or perceived differences between genders.
Category.Example: Why is "Feminism" the "F-word"? Because "Patriarchy" was too long to fit on a t-shirt.
Man: "Honey, why is there a man hiding in our closet?" Woman: "He's looking for Narnia."

Category.Name: British dry humor
Category.Description: A form of comedy characterized by understatement, irony, and a deadpan delivery, often dealing with awkward or absurd situations.
Category.Example: "My hovercraft is full of eels." (Often cited as an example of a nonsensical phrase used in a deadpan way, like from Monty Python).
"It's just a flesh wound." - The Black Knight, Monty Python and the Holy Grail, after having his arm cut off.

Category.Name: Jewish humor
Category.Description: Humor often characterized by self-deprecation, irony, wordplay, and a focus on the anxieties and absurdities of everyday life, often with a historical or cultural subtext.
Category.Example: A man is on his deathbed. He smells his wife's brisket cooking. He calls his son, "Son, go ask your mother for a piece of brisket." The son returns. "Mom says it's for the shiva."
Why don't cannibals eat clowns? Because they taste funny.

Category.Name: Indian PJ jokes
Category.Description: Often referred to as 'Poor Jokes' or 'PJs', these are typically simple, pun-based, or silly jokes popular in India, similar to dad jokes.
Category.Example: Why was the math book sad? Because it had too many problems. (A common PJ)
Teacher: "What is the chemical formula for water?" Student: "HIJKLMNO." Teacher: "What are you talking about?" Student: "Yesterday you said it's H to O!"

Category.Name: Japanese Manzai
Category.Description: A traditional style of stand-up comedy in Japanese culture involving two performers: a tsukkomi (straight man) and a boke (funny man), who trade jokes at great speed. (Note: Example describes the dynamic).
Category.Example: Boke: "I invented a new way to keep my house cool!" Tsukkomi: "Oh really? How?" Boke: "I just open the refrigerator door!" Tsukkomi: "That's not new, and it's terrible for the environment, you idiot!"
Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field! (Could be a line in a Manzai routine).

Category.Name: American stand-up
Category.Description: A broad category of comedy performance where a comedian performs in front of a live audience, usually speaking directly to them, with jokes often based on personal observations, storytelling, or social commentary.
Category.Example: "I was walking down the street, and this guy, he just... you know?" (The humor comes from observational details and delivery, hard to capture in text alone).
"So, I went to the doctor the other day..." (A common setup for an observational or anecdotal joke in stand-up).

Category.Name: Memes
Category.Description: Humorous images, videos, pieces of text, etc., that are copied (often with slight variations) and spread rapidly by Internet users. (Note: Examples are textual descriptions of meme concepts).
Category.Example: Image: Distracted Boyfriend. Text: Boyfriend looking at 'New Programming Language', Girlfriend looking annoyed is 'Current Project', Other Woman is 'Shiny New Framework'.
"One does not simply walk into Mordor." (Text from a popular meme, often adapted).

Category.Name: Dad joke bots / AI-generated
Category.Description: Jokes created by algorithms or AI, often mimicking the style of dad jokes or puns, sometimes with slightly off or absurd results.
Category.Example: Why did the computer go to art school? To learn how to draw a new byte!
What do you call a sad strawberry? A blueberry.

Category.Name: Twitter / Reddit-style jokes
Category.Description: Short, often topical or observational jokes, frequently using hashtags, abbreviations, or specific platform conventions.
Category.Example: Me: I should eat healthier. Also me: *orders pizza with extra cheese* #relatable
Just saw someone pay for coffee with a check. Pretty sure I time-traveled. #oldschool

Category.Name: TikTok punchlines / Vine-style shorts
Category.Description: Very short, often visual jokes or skits with a quick setup and punchline, popular on short-form video platforms. (Note: Examples are textual descriptions).
Category.Example: Video: Person struggles to open a jar. Second person walks in, opens it effortlessly, and walks out. First person looks defeated.
Someone tries a "life hack" from the internet, and it fails spectacularly.

Category.Name: Shitposts / Absurd Gen-Z humor
Category.Description: A type of internet humor characterized by its intentionally low quality, nonsensical, ironic, or surreal content, often defying traditional joke structures.
Category.Example: E
Why did the banana go to the doctor? Because it wasn't peeling well. (Then an image of a distorted banana).
